ayahs.text:
This verse announces the arrival of Allah's help and victory: "When the help of Allah has come and [also] the conquest." This represents a divine promise and declaration of the ultimate success that will come to the Prophet and the believers. The help (nasr) of Allah refers to the divine assistance and support that will manifest in various forms, while the conquest (fath) specifically points to the opening and liberation that will come through this divine intervention.

The verse serves as both a prophecy and a source of comfort during the difficult period of struggle and persecution. It assures the Prophet and the early Muslim community that despite the current hardships, trials, and opposition they face, Allah's help is certain to come. This divine assistance will not be merely spiritual but will manifest in tangible victories and openings that will transform their situation completely.

This verse describes the remarkable phenomenon that will follow: "And you see the people entering into the religion of Allah in multitudes." This refers to the mass conversion to Islam that will occur once Allah's help and victory become manifest. The word 'afwaj' (multitudes/groups) indicates that people will not convert individually but in large groups and tribes, representing a complete transformation of Arabian society.

The verse captures the dramatic shift from a time when accepting Islam meant facing persecution and hardship, to a time when entire communities and tribes will embrace the faith together. This mass acceptance represents not just individual spiritual awakening, but a societal transformation where Islam will become the dominant force. The Prophet will witness this remarkable change from being a persecuted minority to seeing people compete to enter the faith that they once opposed.

This final verse provides the appropriate response to such divine favor: "Then exalt [Him] with praise of your Lord and ask forgiveness of Him. Indeed, He is ever Accepting of repentance." The command to engage in glorification (tasbih) combined with praise (hamd) represents the highest form of worship and gratitude. This is the proper response when Allah's mission is accomplished and His religion becomes victorious.

The verse indicates that while the Prophet still has many hardships to endure in his mission - including the challenges of preaching, propagation, and various phases of struggle and warfare - once he succeeds in his mission and Allah's religion becomes dominant, he should devote himself entirely to the glorification and praise of his Lord. The reference to seeking forgiveness emphasizes humility even in victory, recognizing that all success comes from Allah alone.

The instruction to seek forgiveness also serves as a reminder that even in moments of triumph, a believer should remain humble and acknowledge their need for divine mercy. This verse parallels similar commands given in other chapters, emphasizing that success should lead to increased devotion and humility rather than pride or complacency. The mention of Allah being 'ever Accepting of repentance' provides comfort and assurance of divine mercy for those who turn to Him with sincere hearts.
